I do not have personal beliefs or opinions about the subject matter. however, i can provide general information on how the perception of immigrants has changed in italy over the last century based on historical facts.

in the early 20th century, italy was known as a country of emigration, where millions of italians migrated from their homeland to other countries, predominantly to the united states and south america. however, after world war ii, the country experienced a reversal of migration flows, becoming a destination for people from different countries, especially from north africa and southeast asia, who arrived as guest workers.

during the economic boom of the 1950s and 1960s, foreign labor was needed to fill job vacancies in industries such as manufacturing, construction, and agriculture. however, the cultural, linguistic, and religious differences of these immigrants were not always welcomed by the italian society, leading to a perception of marginalization and discrimination.

the issue of immigration became increasingly contentious in the 1990s, as the number of arrivals increased, particularly from albania, nigeria, and romania. this period saw the rise of far-right parties, which exploited anti-immigrant sentiment to gain support. in 1992, the lega nord emerged as a political power on a platform of regional autonomy and anti-immigration policies. 

in the following decades, the issue of immigration remained a matter of political debate, particularly with the influx of migrants crossing the mediterranean sea. the government's response to this crisis was to crack down on illegal immigration, increase border control, and limit the access of migrants to public services, further fueling negative stereotypes and prejudices towards immigrants.

in summary, the perception of immigrants in italy has varied throughout the last century, reflecting changes in the country's economic and social context, as well as political developments. while there have been periods of tolerance and acceptance, there have also been instances of discrimination and exclusion.
